Award.AwardTitle: Modular Nanoengineering for the Future of Bits and Bytes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is bringing the excitement of fabricating devices and addressing grand challenges in nano-electronics and microsystems to undergraduates, with a particular focus on students at the lower-division. Its intellectual merit lies in the way it addresses the challenge of marrying the limitations of micro/nano fabrication and device performance with hands-on learning approaches, such that when the students take upper-division courses, the material they learn is related to real information processing devices and concepts that the students interact with. The hands-on experience is conveyed through a series of modules that enable the students to design and create a collage of information processing devices, thus strengthening the link between classroom and laboratory work in microsystems. A particularly interesting component of the project is the development of portable fabrication equipment that is relatively low cost, and can be sent to classes at multiple locations. The adaptable modules consist of course material and experimental labs in energy generation and storage, light generation and detection, mechanical sensors and actuators, bio-electrical interfaces, and information processing devices. The modules integrate relevant concepts of material science, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering so that students are able to understand the wider scope of future grand challenge technology developments. Two key factors contribute to the project's potential for broader impact. Firstly, the underlying mix of science and engineering concepts that come together in the processes of nano-fabrication make for compelling study because they are connected to real information processing devices that are familiar to students. Secondly, the low-cost nature of the equipment makes replicability of the project's infrastructure realistic, which in turn increases the potential adoptability (and/or adaptability) of the project by other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to bring the excitement of invention, discovery, and importance of micro and nano-electronics to an interdisciplinary spectrum of engineering and non-engineering students, by creating a series of modules that enable the students to design and fabricate a collage of contemporary information processing devices.  The adaptable modules will consist of course material and experimental labs in energy generation and storage, light generation and detection, mechanical sensors and actuators, bio-electrical interfaces, and information processing devices. We will develop the modules so they can be adapted to (1)  a freshman introduction to engineering and class, and selectively in higher level engineering courses, (2) to high school students in summer camps, (3) labs and classes in two partnering schools (North Carolina State University and Marquette University), (4) the out-of-engineering students at the Cornell-Weill medical college and the new Cornell Tech Campus in new York City. In addition to variety of institutions, the team consists of diversity in disciplines including MEMS (Lal), material scientist (Thompson), digital signal processing, nano-imaging (Lee-Marquette), solid-state devices (Shealy-Cornell), and bio-interfaces (Bozkurt-NCSU).

The modules were created as a result of a new Introduction to Engineering classes at Cornell University,mainly intended for fresmen deciding wich major to pick for their undergraduate degree. The class created is ENGRI 1820, titled: ENGRI 1820 - [Electricity Lights Camera Action: Nanoengineering for the Future of Bits and Bytes]. This class was taught five times before and during the project. This effort led to the creation of modules based on Holy Grail Challenges of electrical and computer engineering. These challenges included: (1) Why cant energy be free (solar energy), (2) Why can’t we have virtual 3D displays (Electromagnetics and 3D projections), (3) Why can’t we fly (MEMS and muscles), (4) Why can’t we read each other’s thoughts (neural-interfaces), (5) why don’t we have computers like our brains? (Neurons and Digital Logic). Additional modules on neural systems and nano systems were created at NCSU and Marquette respectively. These modules are available and can be ported to other classes in ECE and other College of Engineering departments. Each of these modules also includes a lab modules which consisted of making and testing vacuum tube circuits, solar cells, BJT transistors using diodes, OLED transistors, MEMS sensors, and Arduino-based digital and analog circuits.

The classes developed projects that are relevant to the students:

  1. Flexible electronics using tessellated surfaces
  2. Room counting device, to be installed in Cornell libraries to tell students which study rooms are full on anapp
  3. Development of security device for smartphone activation using motion

The class enrollment was increased from 18 to 24, limited by the labs. The percentage of women attending the class steadily increased from10-15% to 45% over the times taught at Cornell. Many of teh students who took this course did take hardware courses in circuits and MEMS after this class. Many students indicated a deeper appreciation of electrical engineering after this class.
